What is the residue modulo $13$ of the sum of the modulo $13$ inverses of the first $12$ positive integers?

Express your answer as an integer from $0$ to $12$, inclusive.

The modulo $13$ inverse of $n$ is the unique integer $x$ such that $nx \equiv 1 \pmod{13}$.
We have 

$$1^{-1} \equiv 1 \pmod{13},$$ $$2^{-1} \equiv 7 \pmod{13},$$ $$3^{-1} \equiv 9 \pmod{13},$$ $$4^{-1} \equiv 10 \pmod{13},$$ $$5^{-1} \equiv 12 \pmod{13},$$ $$6^{-1} \equiv 11 \pmod{13},$$ $$7^{-1} \equiv 8 \pmod{13},$$ $$8^{-1} \equiv 6 \pmod{13},$$ $$9^{-1} \equiv 4 \pmod{13},$$ $$10^{-1} \equiv 3 \pmod{13},$$ $$11^{-1} \equiv 2 \pmod{13},$$ $$12^{-1} \equiv 5 \pmod{13}.$$
Therefore,
$$1^{-1} + 2^{-1} + 3^{-1} + 4^{-1} + 5^{-1} + 6^{-1} + 7^{-1} + 8^{-1} + 9^{-1} + 10^{-1} + 11^{-1} + 12^{-1} \equiv $$ $$1 + 7 + 9 + 10 + 12 + 11 + 8 + 6 + 4 + 3 + 2 + 5 \equiv 78 \equiv \boxed{0} \pmod{13}.$$

Final Answer: $\boxed{0}$. I hope it is correct.
